sentences.sentence: One striking thing about our Platinum 70 Year history of The Australian Financial Review has been the contemporary relevance of issues that dominated the news and opinion pages across the past seven decades.
On Friday, the Financial Review will feature Andrew Clark's latest instalment of his decade-by-decade series, which will chronicle the events of the "noughties", the decade from 2000.

This coincides with the Morrison government's signalling that the 2022 budget will include some version of the fuel excise tax changes that the Howard government included in the 2001 budget ahead of the federal election later that year.

What the Financial Review editorialised in 2001 against John Howard's fuel excise election bribe stands today as the permanent case against what the Morrison government might do in next Tuesday night's budget.Back then, our editorials stressed that petrol prices - which were then pushing up about the $1 a litre mark amid a global oil shock - were determined by import parity pricing, which Mr Howard had introduced as treasurer in 1976.
That exposure to the international oil price, we argued, meant it was "deluding people" to think that the fuel excise changes would make a significant difference to petrol prices.
The 1.5Â¢ per litre cut to the excise and abolition of automatically increasing it by the overall rate of inflation, we warned, "might simply disappear in normal market price movements".

That pointlessness was shown when the Howard government's excise changes had no immediate effect on the cost of filling up at the petrol pump.Two decades on, the Russia-Ukraine war oil price shock has pushed the price of petrol to $2.20 a litre.
But the same arguments against a repeat dose of fuel excise fiddling remain salient.
This includes what we called the "environmental benefits" of taxing fossil fuels, which also helped "reduce dependence on the OPEC cartel".

That is even more relevant today in a world headed towards net zero carbon emissions, and in which the world's fourth largest oil producer - and now leading global bad actor - Russia, has allied with OPEC in the rigging of global oil supplies.
We also urged replacing fuel excise with an explicit road user charge.

That reform is more urgent today amid the climate change-driven shift to electric vehicles, which needs to be accompanied by a shift to user-pays charging for all vehicles to help price the scarce resource of the road network.The bottom line, as in 2001, remains the integrity of the budget.
However, the Howard government's fuel excise changes cut that year's budget surplus by $1.5 billion to $3.2 billion.

With the public finances pushed deep into the red by the pandemic, making a start on fiscal repair and sharpening the incentives to generate income should be the Morrison government's budget priority.
Politicised petrol handouts that will in reality make at best a marginal difference to cost-of-living pressures on voters should be ruled as simply unaffordable.
That's on top of being permanently pointless.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: One striking thing about our Platinum 70 Year history of The Australian Financial Review has been the contemporary relevance of issues that dominated the news and opinion pages across the past seven decades. On Friday, the Financial Review will feature Andrew Clark's latest instalment of his decade-by-decade series, which will chronicle the events of the "noughties", the decade from 2000. This coincides with the Morrison government's signalling that the 2022 budget will include some version of the fuel excise tax changes that the Howard government included in the 2001 budget ahead of the federal election later that year. What the Financial Review editorialised in 2001 against John Howard's fuel excise election bribe stands today as the permanent case against what the Morrison government might do in next Tuesday night's budget.Back then, our editorials stressed that petrol prices - which were then pushing up about the $1 a litre mark amid a global oil shock - were determined by import parity pricing, which Mr Howard had introduced as treasurer in 1976. That exposure to the international oil price, we argued, meant it was "deluding people" to think that the fuel excise changes would make a significant difference to petrol prices. The 1.5Â¢ per litre cut to the excise and abolition of automatically increasing it by the overall rate of inflation, we warned, "might simply disappear in normal market price movements". That pointlessness was shown when the Howard government's excise changes had no immediate effect on the cost of filling up at the petrol pump.Two decades on, the Russia-Ukraine war oil price shock has pushed the price of petrol to $2.20 a litre. But the same arguments against a repeat dose of fuel excise fiddling remain salient. This includes what we called the "environmental benefits" of taxing fossil fuels, which also helped "reduce dependence on the OPEC cartel". That is even more relevant today in a world headed towards net zero carbon emissions, and in which the world's fourth largest oil producer - and now leading global bad actor - Russia, has allied with OPEC in the rigging of global oil supplies. We also urged replacing fuel excise with an explicit road user charge. That reform is more urgent today amid the climate change-driven shift to electric vehicles, which needs to be accompanied by a shift to user-pays charging for all vehicles to help price the scarce resource of the road network.The bottom line, as in 2001, remains the integrity of the budget. However, the Howard government's fuel excise changes cut that year's budget surplus by $1.5 billion to $3.2 billion. This time it's different. With the public finances pushed deep into the red by the pandemic, making a start on fiscal repair and sharpening the incentives to generate income should be the Morrison government's budget priority. Politicised petrol handouts that will in reality make at best a marginal difference to cost-of-living pressures on voters should be ruled as simply unaffordable. That's on top of being permanently pointless.
